{{Discrimination sidebar}} {{Youth rights sidebar}} '''Adultism''' is ''"the power adults have over children"''.<ref name="Flasher1978">{{Cite journal | last1 = Flasher | first1 = J. | year = 1978 | title = Adultism | url = | journal = Adolescence | volume = 13 | issue = 51| pages = 517–523 | pmid = 735921 }}</ref> More narrowly, adultism is defined as ''"prejudice and accompanying systematic discrimination against young people"''.<ref>J. Gregoire/C. M. Jungers, ''The Counsellor's Companion'' (2007) p. 65</ref> On a more philosophical basis, the term has also been defined as ''"bias towards adults... and the social addiction to adults, including their ideas, activities, and attitudes"''.<ref name="Fletcher2013">{{Cite book | last1 = Fletcher | first1 = A. | year = 2013 | title = Ending Discrimination Against Young People | publisher = CommonAction Publishing | location = Olympia, WA }}</ref>
== Etymology ==
=== Coinage ===
The word adultism was used by Patterson Du Bois in 1903,<ref>Patterson Du Bois, ''Fireside Child-Study'' (1903) p. 17</ref> and appears in French [[psychology]] literature in 1929, describing the influence of adults over children. It was seen as a condition wherein a child possessed adult-like "physique and [[spirit]]", and was exemplified by, :A boy of 12 and a girl of 13 who had the spirit and personality of adults.... They were placed in institutions because of stealing and prostitution. These forms of precocity lead the individual into difficulties and should be recognized early in the development of the individual.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Courbon | first1 = P. | year = 1933 | title = Mental adultism and precocious growth of the personality | url = | journal = Annales médico-psychologiques | volume = 87 | issue = | pages = 355–362 }}</ref>
This definition was superseded by a late 1970s journal article proposing that adultism is the abuse of the power that adults have over children. The author identified examples of adultism not only in parents but in teachers, psychotherapists, the clergy, police, judges, and juries.<ref name="Flasher1978" />
=== Usage ===
Adultism is defined as the "behaviors and attitudes based on the assumptions that adults are better than young people, and entitled to act upon young people without agreement".<ref name="Bell1995">Bell, J. (1995) [http://www.youthbuild.org/site/apps/nlnet/content3.aspx?c=htIRI3PIKoG&b=4808015&ct=6640437 "Understanding Adultism: A Major Obstacle to Developing Positive Youth-Adult Relationships"]{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}. [[YouthBuild USA]]. Retrieved 9/2/11.</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Gong|first1=Jennifer|last2=Wright|first2=Dana|title=The Context of Power: Young People as Evaluators|journal=American Journal of Evaluation|date=September 2007|volume=28|issue=3|pages=327–333|doi=10.1177/1098214007306680}}</ref> It is also seen as, "an addiction to the attitudes, ideas, beliefs, and actions of adults."<ref>[http://www.freechild.org/adultism.htm Introduction to Adultism]. [[Freechild Project]]. Retrieved 4/4/10.</ref> Adultism is popularly used to describe any [[discrimination]] against young people and is distinguished from [[ageism]], which is simply prejudice on the grounds of age; not specifically against youth. Adultism is ostensibly caused by fear of [[fear of children|children]] and [[fear of youth|youth]].<ref>Scraton, P. (1997) ''"Childhood" in "crisis"?'' Routledge. p. 25.</ref> It has been suggested that 'adultism, which is associated with a view of the self that trades on rejecting and excluding child-subjectivity, has always been present in Western culture'.<ref>David Kennedy, ''The Well of Being''(2006) p. 67</ref>
Fletcher<ref name="ReferenceA">Fletcher2013</ref> suggests that adultism has three main expressions throughout society: * '''Attitudinal Adultism''': Personal feelings, assumptions, and beliefs that form a person’s attitudes about young people. This is also called ''internalized adultism''. * '''Cultural Adultism''': The shared attitudes, including beliefs and customs, promoting the assumption that adults are superior to anyone who is not identified as an adult, simply because of their age. This is also called ''social adultism''. * '''Structural Adultism''': The normalization and legitimization of historical, cultural, institutional and interpersonal dynamics that routinely advantage adults while producing cumulative and chronic adverse outcomes for young people. This is also referred to as ''institutional adultism''.
A study by the Crisis Prevention Institute of the prevalence of adultism found an increasing number of local youth-serving organizations addressing the issue.<ref>Tate, Thomas F. and Copas, Randall L. (Spring 2003) "Insist or Enlist?: Adultism versus Climates of Excellence," ''Reclaiming Children and Youth: The Journal of Strength-based Interventions, v12'' n1. p 40-45.</ref> For instance, a local program in [[Oakland, California|Oakland]], [[California]], describes the impact of adultism, which "hinders the development of youth, in particular, their self-esteem and self-worth, ability to form positive relationships with caring adults, or even see adults as allies", on their website.<ref>[http://www.youthtogether.net/mcm/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=5&Itemid=39 Youth Together Glossary] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070623094428/http://www.youthtogether.net/mcm/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=5&Itemid=39 |date=June 23, 2007 }}. Youth Together. Retrieved 4/1/2008.</ref>
=== Similar terms ===
Adultism is used to describe the oppression of children and young people by adults, which is seen as having the same power dimension in the lives of young people as racism and sexism.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Roche|first1=Jeremy|title=Children: Rights, Participation and Citizenship|journal=Childhood|date=November 1999|volume=6|issue=4|pages=475–493|doi=10.1177/0907568299006004006}}</ref> It is treated as a generalization of [[paternalism]], allowing for the broad force of adulthood beyond males, and may be witnessed in the infantalization of children and youth. [[Pedophobia]] (the fear of children) and [[ephebiphobia]] (the fear of youth) have been proposed as the antecedents to adultism.<ref>Fletcher, A. (2006) ''Washington Youth Voice Handbook'' Olympia, WA: CommonAction.</ref> [[Tokophobia]], the fear of childbirth, may also be a precursor; [[gerontophobia]], or its antonym, [[gerontocracy]], may be extensions of adultism.{{Citation needed|date=May 2007}}
Similar terms such as adult privilege, adultarchy, and [[adultcentrism]] have been proposed as alternatives which are more [[Morphology (linguistics)|morphologically]] parallel.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.youthrights.org/threetypes.php |title=Three Types of Youth Liberation: Youth Equality, Youth Power, Youth Culture |first=Sven |last=Bonnichsen |publisher=National Youth Rights Association |accessdate=January 4, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110201231951/http://www.youthrights.org/threetypes.php |archivedate=February 1, 2011 }}</ref> Some activists alternatively call adultism "youthism," or "childism" equating it to [[sexism]] and [[heterosexism]].<ref>[http://www.zmag.org/dominickint.htm Youth Liberation: An Interview With Brian Dominick on Znet] {{webarchive|url=https://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20070807052120/http://www.zmag.org/dominickint.htm |date=August 7, 2007 }}</ref> The opposite of adultism is [[jeunism]], which is defined as the preference of young people and adolescents over adults.
At least one prominent organization describes discrimination against youth as [[ageism]], which is any form of discrimination against anyone due to their age. The [[National Youth Rights Association]] argues that ageism is a more natural and understandable term than adultism and thus is more commonly used among the young people affected by this discrimination.<ref>[http://www.youthrights.org/forums/showthread.php?t=2188 Thread from National Youth Rights Association Online Forums re: Ageism vs. Adultism] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060824103141/http://www.youthrights.org/forums/showthread.php?t=2188 |date=August 24, 2006 }}. Retrieved 7/20/08.</ref> Advocates of using 'ageism' also believe it makes common cause with older people fighting against their own form of age discrimination.<ref>[http://oneandfour.org/archives/2005/10/ageism_vs_adult.html [[Alex Koroknay-Palicz]]'s blog] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060523205237/http://oneandfour.org/archives/2005/10/ageism_vs_adult.html |date=May 23, 2006 }}. Retrieved 7/20/08.</ref> However, a national organization called [[Youth On Board]] counters this, arguing that "addressing adultist behavior by calling it ageism is discrimination against youth in itself."<ref>Young, K & Sazama, J (2006) ''15 Points to Successfully Involving Youth in Decision-Making.'' Boston: [http://www.youthonboard.org Youth On Board].</ref>
== Causes ==
In his seminal 1978 article, Flasher explained that adultism is born of the belief that children are inferior, professing that adultism can be manifested as excessive nurturing, possessiveness, or over-restrictiveness, all of which are consciously or unconsciously geared toward excessive control of a child.<ref>Flasher, J. (1978) Adultism. Adolescence 13(51) Fal 1978, 521.</ref> It has been associated with [[psychological projection]] and [[Splitting (psychology)|splitting]], a process whereby 'the one with the power attributes his or her unconscious, unresolved sexual and aggressive material' to the child - 'both the dark and the light side...hence the [[Child (archetype)|divine child]]/deficit child'<ref>Kennedy, p. 64</ref> split.
Recently, theologians Heather Eaton and Matthew Fox proposed, "Adultism derives from adults repressing the inner child."<ref>Eaton, H & Fox, M. "Chapter 10: Transcendent Spirit: Child Honoring and Religion." in Cavoukian, R. (Ed) & Olfman, S. (Ed). (2006). ''Child honoring: How to turn this world around.'' Westport, CT: Praeger Publishers/Greenwood Publishing Group.</ref> [[John Caldwell Holt|John Holt]] stated, "An understanding of adultism might begin to explain what I mean when I say that much of what is known as [[children's art]] is an adult invention."<ref>Holt, J. (Ed) ''Teach your own: The John Holt book of homeschooling.'' Perseus Publishing.</ref> That perspective is seemingly supported by [[Maya Angelou]], who remarked: {{cquote|We are all creative, but by the time we are three or four years old, someone has knocked the creativity out of us. Some people shut up the kids who start to tell stories. Kids dance in their cribs, but someone will insist they sit still. By the time the creative people are ten or twelve, they want to be like everyone else.<ref>{{cite web |author1=Iraki, X.N. |author2=Mukurima, Muriuki |url=http://www.timesnews.co.ke/12jul06/nwsstory/opinion.html|title=Kenya Times News, Opinion--Education new vehicle of a class society |accessdate=2007-03-21| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070317003107/http://www.timesnews.co.ke/12jul06/nwsstory/opinion.html| archivedate= 17 March 2007 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>}}
==Evidence of adultism==
A 2006/2007 survey conducted by the [[Children's Rights Alliance for England]] and the [[National Children's Bureau]] asked 4,060 children and young people whether they have ever been treated unfairly based on various criteria (race, age, sex, sexual orientation, etc.). A total of 43% of British youth surveyed reported experiencing discrimination based on their age, substantially more than other categories of discrimination like sex (27%), race (11%), or sexual orientation (6%).<ref>Willow, C., Franklin, A. and Shaw, C. (2007). Meeting the obligations of the Convention on the Rights of the Child in England. Children and young people's messages to Government. DCSF.</ref>
== Classification ==
In addition to Fletcher,<ref name="ReferenceA"/> other experts have identified multiple forms of adultism, offering a typology that includes internalized adultism,<ref>[http://www.youthonboard.org/atf/cf/%7BDB81B10C-CCBB-46FE-BEF4-011DCFE93F33%7D/GetTheWordOut.pdf Get The Word Out!] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070926003153/http://www.youthonboard.org/atf/cf/%7BDB81B10C-CCBB-46FE-BEF4-011DCFE93F33%7D/GetTheWordOut.pdf |date=2007-09-26 }} Jenny Sazama (2004). p.12</ref> institutionalized adultism,<ref>Hernandez, D. & Rehman, B. (eds). (2002)''Colonize This!: Young Women of Color on Today's Feminism''. Seal Press</ref> cultural adultism, and other forms.
=== Internalized adultism ===
In a publication published by the [[W. K. Kellogg Foundation]], [[University of Michigan]] professor [[Barry Checkoway]] asserts that internalized adultism causes youth to "question their own legitimacy, doubt their ability to make a difference" and perpetuate a "culture of silence" among young people.<ref>[http://www.wkkf.org/pubs/YouthED/Pub564.pdf Adults as Allies] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070926003154/http://www.wkkf.org/pubs/YouthED/Pub564.pdf |date=September 26, 2007 }} (1998) WK Kellogg Foundation. Retrieved 4/1/2008.</ref>
"Adultism convinces us as children that children don't really count," reports an investigative study, and it "becomes extremely important to us [children] to have the approval of adults and be 'in good' with them, even if it means betraying our fellow children. This aspect of internalized adultism leads to such phenomena as tattling on our siblings or being the 'teacher's pet,' to name just two examples."
Other examples of internalized adultism include many forms of violence imposed upon children and youth by adults who are reliving the violence they faced as young people, such as [[corporal punishment]], [[sexual abuse]], [[verbal abuse]], and community incidents that include store policies prohibiting youth from visiting shops without adults, and police, teachers, or parents chasing young people from areas without just cause.<ref name="Bell1995" />
=== Institutional adultism === Institutional adultism may be apparent in any instance of [[systemic bias]], where formalized limitations or demands are placed on people simply because of their young age. Policies, laws, rules, organizational structures, and systematic procedures each serve as mechanisms to leverage, perpetuate, and instill adultism throughout society. These limitations are often reinforced through physical force, coercion or police actions and are often seen as double-standards.<ref>Males, M. (1997) ''Framing Youth: 10 Myths about the Next Generation.'' "Courts have explicitly ruled that policy-makers may impose adult responsibilities and punishments on individual youths as if they were adults at the same time laws and policies abrogate adolescents’ rights en masse as if they were children."</ref> This treatment is increasingly seen as a form of [[gerontocracy]].<ref>[http://www.csmonitor.com/2003/0124/p25s04-usmb.html Monitor Breakfast with James Carville and Stanley Greenberg] "This is not class warfare, this is generational warfare. This administration and old wealthy people have declared war on young people. That is the real war that is going on here. And that is the war we've got to talk about." - James Carville</ref><ref>Gatto, J.T. (2002) [http://www.johntaylorgatto.com/underground/toc1.htm The Underground History of American Education] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061210112502/http://www.johntaylorgatto.com/underground/toc1.htm |date=December 10, 2006 }} "Children allowed to take responsibility and given a serious part in the larger world are always superior to those merely permitted to play and be passive. At the age of twelve, [[Admiral Farragut]] got his first command."</ref>
Institutions perpetuating adultism may include the fiduciary, legal, educational, communal, religious, and governmental sectors of a community. [[Social science]] literature has identified adultism as "within the context of the social inequality and the oppression of children, where children are denied human rights and are disproportionately victims of maltreatment and exploitation."<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Lombardo|first1=Lucien|last2=Polonko|first2=Karen A.|title=Interdisciplinary Contributions to the Prevention of Child Maltreatment|journal=International Journal of Interdisciplinary Social Sciences|volume=4|issue=12|pages=89–112|url=http://iji.cgpublisher.com/product/pub.88/prod.945}}</ref>

"Fighting for Hope" (1984) for specific evidence of institutional adultism in healthcare, identified as structural violence. "A third of the 2,000 million people in the developing countries are starving or suffering from malnutrition. Twenty-five per cent of their children die before their fifth birthday... === Cultural adultism === '''Cultural adultism''' is a much more ambiguous, yet much more prevalent, form of [[discrimination]] or intolerance towards youth.{{Citation needed|date=May 2007}} Any restriction or exploitation of people because of their young age, as opposed to their ability, comprehension, or capacity, may be said to be adultist. These restrictions are often attributed to euphemisms afforded to adults on the basis of age alone, such as "better judgment" or "the wisdom of age". A parenting magazine editor comments, "Most of the time people talk differently to kids than to adults, and often they act differently, too."<ref>[http://www.ru.org/83wright.html Treating children as equals.] Wright, J. New Renaissance Magazine (2001)."</ref> This summarizes cultural adultism. For examples see:
{{Columns-list|3| * [[Aesthetics]]<ref name="Leddy">{{cite journal|last1=Leddy|first1=Thomas|title=Aesthetics and Children's Picture-Books|journal=Journal of Aesthetic Education|date=Winter 2002|volume=36|issue=4|pages=43–54|doi=10.2307/3301567|jstor=3301567}}</ref> * [[Child abuse]] * [[Youth subculture|Academic misconceptions of youth]] * [[Youth culture|Commercialization]] * [[Content filtering|Online filters]] * [[Corporal punishment]] * [[Children's literature]] * [[Child labor]] * [[Teen idol|Mass marketing to youth]] * [[Peer pressure]] * [[Child prostitution]] * [[Sagging (fashion)#Controversy|Controversy over sagging]] * [[Scapegoat#Political/sociological scapegoating|Scapegoating]] * Stereotypes about [[List of youth subcultures|Youth subculture]] * [[Teen sex]] * [[Drinking age]] * [[Generation gap]] * [[poverty]] * [[unemployment]] gaps in ages 18 to 25 * [[Moralism]] * [[Mental illness]] * [[Runaway (dependent)|Runaways]] }}
== Results ==
=== Social stratification === Discrimination against age is increasingly recognized as a form of [[bigotry]] in social and cultural settings around the world. An increasing number of social institutions are acknowledging the positions of children and teenagers as an [[oppression|oppressed]] [[Minority group#Age minorities|minority group]].<ref>(2006) ''15 Points to Successfully Involving Youth in Decision-Making.'' Boston: Youth On Board. p 95.</ref> Many youth are rallying against the adultist myths spread through mass media from the 1970s through the 1990s. <ref>(2004) [https://web.archive.org/web/20060718010357/http://www.movementstrategy.org/pdfs/MSMC.pdf "Making Space - Making Change: Profiles of Youth-Led and Youth-Driven Organizations"]. Movement Strategy Center. p 17. Retrieved 9/7/07.</ref><ref>Giroux, H. "The Abandoned Generation: Democracy Beyond the Culture of Fear" (2003).</ref>
Research compiled from two sources (a Cornell University nationwide study, and a Harvard University study on youth) has shown that social stratification between age groups causes [[stereotype|stereotyping]] and generalization; for instance, the media-perpetuated myth that all adolescents are immature, violent and rebellious.<ref>(2006) ''15 Points to Successfully Involving Youth in Decision-Making.'' Boston: Youth On Board. p 94.</ref> Opponents of adultism contend that this has led to growing number of youth, academics, researchers, and other adults rallying against adultism and ageism, such as organizing education programs, protesting statements, and creating organizations devoted to publicizing the concept and addressing it.<ref name="Decision-Making. p 92">(2006) ''15 Points to Successfully Involving Youth in Decision-Making.'' Boston: Youth On Board. p 92.</ref>
Simultaneously, research shows that young people who struggle against adultism within community organizations have a high rate of impact upon said agencies, as well as their peers, the adults who work with them, and the larger community to which the organization belongs<ref>Zeldin, S, Kusgen-McDaniel, A, & Topitzes, D. [http://www.theinnovationcenter.org/pdfs/Youth_in_Decision_Making_Report.pdf "Youth In Decision-Making: A Study on The Impacts of Youth on Adults and Organizations"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060819131311/http://www.theinnovationcenter.org/pdfs/Youth_in_Decision_Making_Report.pdf |date=August 19, 2006 }} (2001).</ref>
=== Cultural responses === There may be many negative effects of adultism, including [[ephebiphobia]] and a growing [[generation gap]]. A reactive social response to adultism takes the form of the [[children's rights movement]], led by young people who strike against being exploited for their labor. Numerous popular outlets are employed to strike out against adultism, particularly [[list of songs about school|music]] and movies. Additionally, many youth-led social change efforts have inherently responded to adultism, particularly those associated with [[youth activism]] and [[student activism]], each of which in their own respects have struggled with the effects of institutionalized and cultural adultism.<ref name="Decision-Making. p 92"/>
=== Academic developments === A growing number of governmental, academic, and educational institutions around the globe have created policy, conducted studies, and created publications that respond to many of the insinuations and implications of adultism. Much of popular researcher [[Margaret Mead]]'s work can be said to be a response to adultism.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Mitchell|first1=Lisa M.|title=Child-Centered? Thinking Critically about Children's Drawings as a Visual Research Method|journal=Visual Anthropology Review|date=Spring 2006|volume=22|issue=1|page=68|doi=10.1525/var.2006.22.1.60}}</ref> Current researchers whose work analyzes the effects of adultism include sociologist [[Mike Males]]<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Chu|first1=Julie|title=Navigating the Media Environment: How Youth Claim a Place Through Zines|journal=Social Justice|date=Fall 1997|volume=24|issue=3|pages=71–85|jstor=29767022}}</ref> and critical theorist [[Henry Giroux]]. The topic has recently been addressed in [[liberation psychology]] literature, as well.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Watts|first1=Roderick J.|last2=Flanagan|first2=Constance|title=Pushing the envelope on youth civic engagement: A developmental and liberation psychology perspective|journal=Journal of Community Psychology|date=August 2007|volume=35|issue=6|pages=779–792|doi=10.1002/jcop.20178}}</ref>
== Addressing adultism == Any inanimate or animate exhibition of adultism is said to be "adultist". This may include behaviors, policies, practices, institutions, or individuals.
Educator [[John Caldwell Holt|John Holt]] proposed that teaching adults about adultism is a vital step to addressing the effects of adultism,<ref>Holt, J. (2003) ''Teach Your Own'' Perseus Publishing.</ref> and at least one organization<ref>[http://www.youthonboard.org Youth On Board]</ref> and one curriculum<ref>Creighton, A. & Kivel, P. (1992) ''Helping Teens Stop Violence: A Practical Guide for Counselors, Educators, and Parents'' Hunter House.</ref> do just that. Several educators have created curricula that seek to teach youth about adultism, as well.<ref>Miller-McLemore, B. (2003) ''Let the Children Come: Reimagining Childhood from a Christian Perspective'' Josey-Bass.</ref> Currently, organizations responding to the negative effects of adultism include the United Nations, which has conducted a great deal of research<ref>[https://archive.is/20120915074105/http://www.unicef-icdc.org/cgi-bin/unicef/Lunga.sql?ProductID=384 The Evolving Capacities of the Child] UNICEF. (2005)</ref> in addition to recognizing the need to [[Convention on the Rights of the Child|counter adultism]] through policy and programs. The [[Convention on the Rights of the Child|CRC]] has particular Articles (5 and 12) which are specifically committed to combating adultism. The international organization Human Rights Watch has done the same.<ref>[http://hrw.org/reports/2005/us1005/6.htm The Difference between Youth and Adults] HRW online.</ref>
Common practice accepts the engagement of [[youth voice]] and the formation of [[youth-adult partnership]]s as essential steps to resisting adultism.<ref>(n.d.) [http://freechild.org/adultism.htm Adultism Resources] The Freechild Project website.</ref>
Some ways to challenge adultism also include youth-led programming and participating in [[List of youth organizations|youth-led organizations]]. These are both ways of children stepping up and taking action to call out the bias towards adults. Youth-led programming allows the voices of the youth to be heard and taken into consideration.<ref>https://freechild.org/adultism/</ref> Taking control of their autonomy can help children take control of their sexuality, as well. Moving away from an adultist framework leads to moving away from the idea that children aren't capable of handling information about sex and their own sexuality. Accepting that children are ready to learn about themselves will decrease the amount of misinformation spread to them by their peers and allow them to receive accurate information from individuals educated on the topic.<ref>http://taasa.org/lets-talk-about-sex/</ref>
==Criticism==
In its most extreme form, the target of the advocates of addressing adultism is "the more or less conscious, uncontrolled, and covert exercise of power over the child by the adult ... this wielding of power by adults"<ref>Alice Miller, ''The Drama of Being a Child'' (1995) p. 85</ref> ''per se''. Such an attack on ''any'' adult power may be fuelled by what has been called "the ''homunculus'' idea about children ... to many grown-ups a child is a Small Adult. They do not understand that a child carries different kinds of problems than an adult does".<ref>Eric Berne, ''A Layman's Guide to Psychiatry and Psychoanalysis'' (Penguin 1976) p. 103</ref>
In its milder form, "adultism is about the misuse of power and does not refer to the normal responsibilities of adults in relation to children".<ref>M.-N. Beaudoin/M. Taylor, ''Breaking the Culture of Bullying and Disrespect'' (2004) p. 9</ref> Therefore, "addressing adultism is not about reversing the power structure ... [or] completely eradicating it": rather, "shedding adultism involves a negotiation of decisions".<ref>Beaudoin, p. 129-30</ref>
